channel.title: FOREX.com's Weekly Strategy
channel.description: FOREX.com's Weekly Strategy - Updated every Friday with the latest commentary on the foreign exchange market by Kathleen Brooks, Research Director and the FOREX.com Research Team.

item.title: 06/15/2014 - What's the BOJ's Next Move?
item.description:
* BoJ: I Wish I Knew How to Quit You, QQE
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Global Data Highlights

Finally, the BoJ's version of stimulus is massive in comparison to the rest of the world relative to the size of their economy. While the Bank of England talks about raising interest rates "sooner than the market currently expects" and the Fed tapers QE in to oblivion, the gap between other central banks and the BOJ probably won't get any smaller. As for the European Central Bank, they certainly brought something else to the table, but it likely won't even split the difference between the ECB and the BoJ.

So does the BoJ really need to do anything else at the moment? Considering what it's done so far and the effect those actions have had on inflation to date, it would be hard to argue that more is needed. That being said, if consumption suffers due to the tax increase for a second month in a row, the BoJ may... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 06/08/2014 - Why the ECB May Trump NFP Reports This Summer
item.description:
* More Bark than Bite: ECB Unleashes the Era of Negative Deposit Rates
* Why is the Market Not Reacting to NFP Reports?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Global Data Highlights

If you had looked at the EURUSD rate first thing Thursday morning and then compared it with the rate as we approached the end of the European session, it was pretty flat, give or take a few basis points. However, the calm hides a huge amount of volatility in the single currency and a dramatic step into the unknown from the ECB.

After ECB President Draghi telegraphed the bank's desire to target low inflation at last month's meeting, there was little the Bank could do but act at this meeting. The Bank has thrown the kitchen sink at deflation, and the new actions it has taken includes... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 06/01/2014 - Will the ECB Push Down the EUR?
item.description:
* Will the ECB Push Down the EUR?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Global Data Highlights

Since the last ECB meeting, the EUR has fallen consistently after ECB President Mario Draghi ditched the ECB's policy to never pre-commit to policy action. At last month's meeting, Draghi dropped extensive hints that more policy action is on its way. Although his message was toned down by Bundesbank President Weidmann and others in recent weeks, the market is fully expecting action from the ECB. Last Thursday, the head of the Bank of Spain said that the Bundesbank supports action to beat deflation, which is another reason why we think the ECB will take action this week.

The market expects a troika of measures from the ECB: a small cut of 10-15 basis points to the main benchmark rate, a similar sized cut to the deposit rate (which would take it into negative territory for the first time in Eurozone history), and measures to boost lending to small and medium-sized businesses. While the market... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 05/25/2014 - The New Troika in Town: Inflation, Treasury Yields and the USD
item.description:
* The New Troika in Town: Inflation, Treasury Yields and the USD
* ECB: Getting Closer to Policy Action
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Global Data Highlights

One of the key themes in the market so far this year has been investors' acceptance that Treasury yields could stay low for some time. Hence Treasury yields, although they have picked up this week, remain close to 2.48%, the lowest level since Summer 2013.

But is this justified? Although the US economy struggled at the start of this year, it is getting its groove back and the labour market in particular is showing signs of... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 05/18/2014 - Has ECB price action already been priced in by the market?
item.description:
* Has ECB price action already been priced in by the market?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Global Data Highlights

The May ECB meeting saw a more-animated-than-usual Mario Draghi point to potential policy action at the next ECB meeting in June. Press reports last week suggested that the ECB is working on a range of measures to loosen monetary policy further, and the head of Austria's central bank, Ewald Nowotny, said that a mere cut in the base rate (currently at 0.25%) would likely not be a big enough step. This has led to speculation that the ECB will cut the base rate to 0.10-0.15% and the deposit rate to negative for the first time in the Eurozone's history.

A negative deposit rate is a fairly dramatic action for any central bank to take, especially one as traditionally conservative as the ECB. When deposit rates are cut to negative, it can... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 05/11/2014 - ECB gets ready to act in June
item.description:
* ECB gets ready to act in June
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Global Data Highlights

The EUR tumbled at the end of last week after ECB President Mario Draghi gave a strong hint that the Bank is willing to take action at its meeting next month. It appears that a combination of a strong EUR and weak inflation has tested the patience of the ECB far enough, although Draghi said he would prefer to wait for the next set of ECB staff inflation forecasts (due next month) before he agrees to make a move.

The market seems to be willing to take Draghi at his word. During last week's press conference, Mario Draghi and co-host Belgian Central Bank head Luc Coene seemed to suggest that a cut to the main interest rate, which is currently at 0.25%, and a cut to the deposit rate, which is currently at 0%, would have a bigger impact than just cutting base rates. We think... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 05/04/2014 - Is a strong pound a concern for the UK?
item.description:
* Is a strong pound a concern for the UK?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: French CAC
* Look Ahead: Crude Oil
* Worldwide Fundamental Outlook

Last week the pound rallied above 1.69 to its highest level since August 2009. This has led to some soul-searching, is the pound too strong for the UK's economic recovery? Will the BOE have to intervene? Before you can answer this, it is worth looking at why the pound has been rallying.

A strong currency can be seen as a reflection of a strong economy, and the UK's economy continues to power ahead. We found out last week that the economy was growing at a 3.1% annual pace in the first quarter. Thus, considering the US... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 04/27/2014 - Eurozone CPI Crucial for the ECB
item.description:
* Eurozone CPI Crucial for the ECB
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Don't Bank on More QE in Japan
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

This week's hotly anticipated CPI data could prove to be a "make or break" release for the ECB. The flash reading of April CPI has a lot resting on it: at the last ECB meeting President Draghi acknowledged that prices were low but said that the late timing of Easter should boost prices this month. The market has taken Draghi at his word and is expecting a rise from 0.5% to 0.8%. The actual data could determine whether or not the ECB embarks on QE in the near term.

The prospect of QE from the ECB has dominated financial markets for the last few months, and expectation of largesse from the ECB could be one of the factors that is weighing on FX volatility, which fell to its lowest level since 2007 last week. QE can dampen FX volatility, as we saw with the US dollar in 2009 when...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 04/13/2014 - What is Upsetting Risk Sentiment?
item.description:
* What is Upsetting Risk Sentiment?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* FX Return Analysis
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

At the end of last week risk sentiment took a knock. The VIX, Wall Street's "fear" index, spiked to its highest level since the Ukraine crisis in March, global stock markets sold off sharply and the yen, traditionally a safe haven, was the best performer in the G10 FX space. As we ended the week, major US equity indices were registering year-to-date losses, erasing gains in recent months. So is this the much-hyped selloff in risk that some people have been looking for?

While a few days' price action does not necessarily make a trend, there are some important drivers of this selloff that may keep sellers in the driving seat for the medium-term. First, earnings data for Q1 may be a major headwind. Although only 28 out of the S&P 500 have reported earnings so far, the picture is not looking good, with sales figures surprising on the downside. There have also been some notable misses, including...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 04/06/2014 - A Mixed Payrolls Report Thwarts Dollar Upside
item.description:
* Mixed Payrolls Report Thwarts Dollar Upside
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* The ECB, QE and the EUR
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

While the Non-Farm payrolls report was solid for March, with 192k jobs created and upward revisions to the two prior months' of 37k, the market's initial reaction to the economic thaw seemed fairly tepid on Friday. Treasury yields actually fell 5 basis points, while dollar strength was limited and the dollar index has not been able to get above the crucial 200-day sma at 80.85. So why the muted market reaction when the headline NFP rate was good?

The reason could be two-fold. Firstly, the market had been looking for a good number, and so all of the potential good news was already priced in. Ahead of the payrolls report the dollar index had broken out of its prior range and extended recent gains, likewise...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 03/30/2014 - Fed Chair Yellen may backpedal from 6-month notion
item.description:
* Fed Chair Yellen may backpedal from 6-month notion
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

At the meeting in March, the Fed decided to scale back their asset purchases by another $10B to $55B in April. This decision was well televised by the FOMC, as hawks and doves alike have affirmed the view that scaling back QE is here to stay and that the likely measured reductions to the pace of monthly asset purchases (by $10B) will be unwavering over the coming meetings. As a result, if the current pace of Fed tapering remains on track, then asset purchases are set to come to an end by the beginning of Q4 2014....Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 03/23/2014 - Deciphering the Fed
item.description:
* Deciphering the Fed
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

The jury is out on Janet Yellen's first press conference as Fed governor. After her comments were initially interpreted as being hawkish, as we ended last week the market seemed to reconsider and the S&P 500 broke to a fresh record high. There is still a debate going on as to what Yellen was trying to say and do last Wednesday: the hawks think the Fed was signalling a shorter period of time from when tapering stops and rate hikes start, the doves are putting it down to Yellen's nervousness at her first meeting. In reality it is probably a bit of both.

Post the Fed press conference a slew of dovish Fed members including Minneapolis Kocherlakota were out in force reiterating the need for caution when it came to...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 03/16/2014 - The RBNZ Launches a Prolonged Tightening Cycle
item.description:
* The RBNZ Launches a Prolonged Tightening Cycle
* EM Rundown: Putin on the Risk
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

Last week the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) became the first central bank amongst its G10 counterparts to raise interest rates since 2011. The RBNZ kicked off what is expected to be a lengthy tightening cycle by raising the official cash rate (OCR) by 25bps to 2.75%, citing considerable momentum in the economy and more broad-based GDP growth. RBNZ Governor Wheeler also signaled the potential for a steeper climb in rates than previously thought, which gave investors another reason to flock to the NZ dollar.

Prior to last week, the RBNZ kept the OCR steady at 2.5% for three years in an attempt to stimulate the economy and spur growth. Now, rising house prices are driving up inflation and earthquake reconstruction efforts are providing a solid platform for GDP growth. Inflation is nearing the RBNZ's 2% target midpoint, with consumer prices rising 1.6% last quarter, and is expected to ...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 03/09/2014 - Is risk sentiment back on?
item.description:
* Is risk sentiment back on?
* Will the ECB continue to turn a blind eye to EUR strength?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

Last week was full of extremes. At the start of the week escalating tensions between Russia and the Ukraine dominated sentiment. Risky assets sold off and stocks fell sharply. However by Tuesday, when it looked like a violent outcome to the crisis was off the cards, the markets were able to put the Ukraine crisis to one side and sentiment perked up. Friday's solid US payrolls report provided the icing on the cake for a good week for risk.

Payrolls rose 175k, above the 149k expected, defying some of the bad weather effects from February. The private sector was the key driver of jobs growth, rising 162k last month, led by large gains in the business and service sectors. The weakest areas of jobs growth included ...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 03/02/2014 - A Bad Month for the Buck
item.description:
* A Bad Month for the Buck
* Inflation, the ECB and the EUR
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

The dollar lost ground to all currencies in the G10 bar the yen in February. It has been a weak start to the year for the greenback; the dollar has failed to rally against any G10 currency apart from the Canadian dollar since the start of 2014.

There were various drivers that could have weighed on the USD in February...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 02/23/2014 - The Dollar Starts to Show Signs of Life, but Can It Last?
item.description:
* The Dollar Starts to Show Signs of Life, but Can It Last?
* Can the ECB Get Away with Doing Nothing?
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data Highlights

The greenback had a disappointing start to the year, with the dollar index falling nearly 2% after peaking on Jan 21. However, after dipping to a low of 79.92 last week, it had a mild recovery on the back of the FOMC minutes and some better than expected PMI data for February.

So will it be an early spring for the buck? That could depend on the weather. As temperatures have picked up in recent days so has a sense of optimism. The dollar was able to shrug off weaker Empire and Philadelphia Fed manufacturing surveys last week, instead concentrating on the preliminary nationwide PMI from Markit, which surprised to the upside. The thinking behind the market's selective approach to the data may be ...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 02/16/2014 - The Pressure Eases for Draghi
item.description:
* The Pressure Eases for Draghi
* The Dollar and the Weather Effect
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Data Highlights

The EUR managed to make a two-week high against the USD last week and broke above a key resistance level at 1.3701 - the top of the daily Ichimoku cloud. This is a bullish development, yet the market still seems to be uncomfortable with a strengthening single currency, and the naysayers fear that a collapse is on the cards because the ECB will be forced to take an aggressive easing stance at some stage.

However, over the past week the pressure on the ECB to take further accommodative action to stir the economy has eased. From a data perspective, Q4 GDP surprised on the upside, rising 0.4% last month. The biggest surprise was...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 02/09/2014 - The ECB Leaves the Markets Guessing Once Again
item.description:
* The ECB Leaves the Markets Guessing Once Again
* Market Movers: Weekly Technical Outlook
* Look Ahead: Gold
* Look Ahead: Dow Jones Industrial Average
* Worldwide Fundamental Outlook

The one thing the markets should know by now about ECB President Mario Draghi is that he tends to deliver the unexpected. In the past, when the markets expected the ECB to stay neutral, the Bank has cut rates, and when the market has anticipated fresh dovish measures, it has instead remained on hold. This month was a reminder that the ECB is hard to predict. Ahead of the meeting, some analysts had been looking for a rate cut and/or some new dovish measures like ending bond purchase sterilisation after a weak inflation report for January. However, the ECB surprised the markets once again and refrained from adopting a dovish tone on the back of the January CPI report. The highlights from the press conference include:

  • Inflation: expectations remain firmly anchored, even though the drop in prices in March was a shock. However...Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 02/02/2014 - Has the market turmoil passed?
item.description:
* Has the market turmoil passed?
* Market Movers: weekly technical outlook
* Look Ahead: Stocks
* Look Ahead: Commodities
* Data highlights

This is the big question for investors as we wait for some key event risks this week. Last week's sell off in emerging markets triggered losses elsewhere as investors rotated out of risky assets and into safe havens. The panic started in FX markets and then spread to equity and bond markets, however, by the end of the week the FX markets had calmed down, even though stocks remained under pressure and Treasuries were continuing to attract in-flows keeping the 10-year Treasury yield at a 2-month low.

By the end of last week even some emerging currencies had staged a recovery, including the Turkish lira, which was up some 0.66% against the USD, other outperformers included the Indian rupee and the South Korean won. So were the last few weeks' merely a warning sign for investors reminding them... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 01/26/2014 - Is the Risk Aversion Justified?
item.description:
* Is the Risk Aversion Justified?
* Fundamental Wrap: UK and Europe
* Weekly Outlook: Dow Jones
* Weekly Outlook: Crude Oil
* North American and Asian-Pacific Fundamental Outlook
* Classic Technicals: The Week Ahead

The sharp drop in EM FX and stocks at the end of last week and the rise in safe havens such as Treasuries, the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc, appeared to be fuelled by a few things: 1, fears about China after its January PMI reading fell into contraction territory, 2, concerns over the sustainability of the US economic recovery after some weak economic data and some notable earnings misses in bell-weather companies such as McDonalds and 3, fears that a global tightening cycle is upon us.

To assess whether these fears are justified and if the sell-off in risk has the potential to continue it's worth looking at each of these individually... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 01/19/2014 - Global Fundamental Outlook: Jan 20 - Jan 24
item.description:
* Global Fundamental Outlook: Jan 20 - Jan 24
* Weekly outlook: FTSE
* Weekly outlook: precious metals
* Classic Technicals: The Week Ahead

The past week has been a time of reflection in the currency markets as investors looked toward new data and new speeches to try and get a handle on what exactly is going on in the US economic recovery. The US Non-Farm Payroll release the previous week that frightened so many traders failed to faze Federal Reserve members as they lauded their plan to eliminate Quantitative Easing by marching forward with the tapering program. Further data failed to supplement the notion that NFP was a true representation of the U.S. economy and the scores of related data was somehow wrong.

So in response to the overwhelming tide of information and opinion from policymakers, traders slowly but surely resumed their love affair with the USD as it regained all of the... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 01/12/2014 - NFP and the dollar rebound story
item.description:
* NFP and the dollar rebound story
* ECB joins the doves
* Fundamental wrap UK and Europe
* North American Fundamental Outlook: January 13, 2014 - January 17, 2014
* Weekly outlook: oil
* Weekly outlook: Dow
* Classic Technicals: The Week Ahead

The big shock at the end of last week was the dismal payrolls number for December, which only managed to rise by 74,000. The data was particularly hard to read because it was such a mixed bag: the unemployment rate dropped to 6.7%, yet the participation rate also fell to 62.8% - the lowest level since October, which was the lowest level since 1978. Also on the weak side were average hours worked, which edged down to 34.4 hours per week, down from 34.5 in November and wage growth, which dipped to 1.8% from 2%. However, the November reading was revised higher to 241k from 203k initially, which leaves the average rate for the last three months of 2013 at a relatively healthy 172k.

On the face of it the December reading is a dismal report, however such a negative shock suggests that maybe something else is going on. Could it be weather related? Some analysts posed this as a downside risk prior to the number. Or could it be that holiday-related hiring takes place earlier in the year these days, which leaves... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube

item.title: 01/05/2014 - Twin Fears to haunt the Eurozone
item.description:
* Twin Fears to haunt the Eurozone
* Is France the next domino to fall?
* Is the UK recovery petering out?
* Fundamental outlook: US
* Weekly outlook gold
* Weekly outlook Dow Jones
* Classic Technicals: the week ahead

At the start of the New Year, two concerns are likely to occupy the thoughts of the ECB at this week's meeting. The first, and most important, is deflation. We will get December inflation data this week and prices are likely to remain weak at 0.9%. However, there has been some worrying signs that deflation may start to creep into the currency bloc. Firstly, Italy, who released December CPI data on Friday, saw annual EU harmonised CPI slip to 0.6% from 0.7%, while Spain saw prices remain just above deflation territory at 0.3%. With growth still lacklustre in the currency bloc, deflation is a real threat.

The second problem is the EUR. It was the best performer in the G10 versus the USD last year, and although it has come off the boil at the start of 2014 it is still at growth-dampening levels. EURUSD (at the time of writing) had fallen through the 50-day moving average on Friday ahead of the European close. However, the 1.5% drop since the start of Jan is a mere drop in the ocean... Full text »

Facebook | Twitter | YouTube
